title: Resources on scientific writing
text:
Resources on scientific writing

A syllabus on scientific writing. Including re-arranging old papers following the current IMRaD standard.
A thesaurus is a synonym dictionary, it can be helpful… well, to find synonyms :) If you know what you want to say, but the words you use don’t satisfy you, consult a Thesaurus to check possible synonyms: Merriam-Webster, WordReference.
Practical recommendations on how to write a paper.
CmapTools is a free software to produce conceptual maps, which can be useful ways to organize information.

title: Resources to organize your scripts, improve your workflow, etc
text:
Resources to organize your scripts, improve your workflow, etc


A beginner’s guide to R, R Studio, and the tidyverse.
Primers on data visualization, iteration, writing functions, reproducibility, etc.
Recommendations on style, appropaite naming of objects, etc. You can try the styler package to implement a consistent style.
Don’t repeat yourself (DRY). Write functions instead of copy-pasting code.
Rodríguez-Sánchez, F. 2020. Quince consejos para mejorar nuestro código y flujo de trabajo con R. Ecosistemas 29(3): 2129.
You can also read this Twitter thread.
A wealth of resources.
Keep track of all the parentheses in your code by colouring each pair of brackets in a different color: Tools > Global options > Code > Display > Use rainbow parentheses
A comparison across repositories (Dryad vs Zenodo vs Figshare vs others).
Some recommendations on how to name your files, specially relevant for manuscripts.
Tabular data may be in long or wide format, the switch between the two is called “pivotting”, of which you can change a nice animation here.

title: Analysis of data
text:
Common statistical tests (t-test, chi-square test) are linear models, which is relevant when it comes to teaching statistics.





An interesting visualization of how mixed models pool information and the effect of shrinkage.





Frequently asked questions on Generalized Linear Mixed Models (GLMM).





GAMMs: using random effects in GAMs
Interactive course on GAMs by Noam Ross





Sillero et al. (2023) A curated list of R packages for ecological niche modelling.
Peterson et al. (2022) ENM2020: A free online course and set of resources on modeling species niches and distributions.





Simpson’s paradox: a trend revealed by a dataset can reverse when the dataset is split into groups. It is related to the ecological fallacy: a mistaken deductive reasoning, in which we try to draw conclusions about individuals based on data collected at the group level. Some claim that the paradox does not exist.
Lecture: The foundations of causal inference.
Lecture: Science before statistics: causal inference.





David Zelený’s webpage contains theory, and R functions and examples on ordination analysis, numerical classification, community-weighted-mean, fourth corner methods & RLQ, and diversity analysis.





Overview of how the R ecosystem for performing GIS operations has changed, including equivalencies among packages. Note that some packages are scheduled to “retired” in October 2023, and learning to use the modern alternatives is important.





Measure how much time it takes for a chunk of code to run, tictoc and microbenchmark are good options.
Multiple ways to optimize running time.
Some functions run models in a fast way, particularly useful when dealing with large datasets: glmmTMB::glmmTMB() (generalized linear mixed models with Template Model Builder), mgcv::bam() (big additive models).
Some processes can be parallelized. For instance, glmmTMB::glmmTMB() (a fast way to fit GLM(M)s) and MuMIn::dredge() (fit all combinations of explanatory variables, can be combined with multimodel inference).

title: CREAFuture
text:
Are you making the PhD at the CREAF and you would say any of the following statemets?

I told my supervisors that I knew how to code but I have no idea.

Statistics? But my PhD is in ecology!

Welcome to CREAFuture Github: the webpage where you can acknowledge without fear (supervisors) your coding and statistic problems.



photo 7665






To share basic coding and statistics information
To ask for help






Start an issue!
Feel free to ask in any language you want, think of it as your question.
Follow tehse six steps and start to ask:

Go to the issue section
Start a new issue
Write a title for the issue
Explain your issue, if you want to format your comment you can use the following guide: https://docs.github.com/es/get-started/writing-on-github/getting-started-with-writing-and-formatting-on-github/basic-writing-and-formatting-syntax
Add a label to the issue, for example, help wanted if you need help
Submit the comment




image





You are lucky because we have a lot of very useful ones here The main CREAFuture repository is divided into five sections:

Theory resources: Here you will find references, books of different ecology fields
Data management: Here you will find resources to start coding and to manage your data.
Data collection: Here you will find resources to obtein and to collect data from the web.
Data visualization: Here you will find resources to visualizate your data.
Data analysis - Statistics: Here you will find resources to visualizate your data.

All the sections have documents like this one explaining in detail the information they contain.

title: Resources to get data sets
text:
R comes with some standard data sets, check “data()” or the datasets package. It is common for R packages to contain data sets that demonstrate functions.





Knowledge Network for Biodiversity (KNB) is an international repository of ecological data sets. At the time of writing (24th March 2023) it stores over 28,000 datasets., with uneven geographical coverage. Find a light introduction to its use here.
Environmental Data Initiative (EDI) archives a lot of environmental data that comes from publicly-funded research, in particular, Long-Term Ecological research (LTER) in the USA. Find a light introduction to its use here.
National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is a network of field sites across the USA that regularly collect ecological data. Find a light introduction to its use here.





Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF)
Ocean Biodiversity Information System (OBIS): like GBIF for marine species. Find a light introduction to its use here.




Indeed, some webpages aggregate or provide convenient lists of pre-existing repositories,

DataONE aggregates data sets from several repositories and organizations (including the already mentioned KNB, EDI and NEON). At the time of writing (24th March 2023) it stores over 840,000 datasets, with uneven geographical coverage.
Central Michigan University Library hosts a great list of resources, including ecological, organismal and environmental data.





Code to get data from the LEDA trait database.
Two amusing examples (not ecology-related): webscrapping Pokémon statistics and pictures, and webscrapping ratings for The Simpsons over time.

title: Data visualization
text:
A collection of links on data visualization in general and ggplot2





Find which graph is best suited to tell you story checking the R graph gallery, a comprehensive gallery of different types of graphs and charts.
R Graphics cookbook offers more than 150 recipes to create many types of graphs.
Boxplots can be improved by showing the distribution of data, for instance by plotting jittered and transparent points, or by combining them with violin plots. If you overlay the points on the boxplot, remember to set “outlier.shape = NA”, otherwise you will plot outlying plots twice!
The classic correlation matrix plots pairwise correlation among continuous variables. A handy extension including continuous and categorical variables can be implemented with the ggpairs() function from the GGally package.
Quick and easy ways to deal with long labels.: rotat the labels, rotate the axes, use scales::label_wrap()…





Phlyopic is an open database of free silhouetes of plants, animals and other life forms. Convenient to create phylogenetic trees, etc.
To choose color palettes, try the Color Brewer webpage, which allows to compare multiple types of color palettes (diverging values, qualitative, etc), taking into account colour-blindness! Coolors allows to browse palettes, check the contrast between coloured background and coloured text, create a palette from a picture, etc





Data visualization can also be done in Python, for instance with the seaborn library, examples here.
